content.title: Humans perceive frequency of sound waves as pitch aka musical note
texts: Since sound is a wave that goes up and down, the number of times it goes up and down within a certain amount of time is called frequency.

The standard unit of measure of frequency is the Hertz, noted as Hz. 1 Hz means, «the wave goes up, down and back to the starting point in 1 second». The higher the frequency, the sharper the sound. Inversely, the lower the frequency, the flatter the sound.

content.title: Amplitude of wave aka volume
content.text: The standard unit of measure of amplitude of the sound wave, more commonly known as volume, is the Decibel, noted as dB. It represents the distance between the highest and lowest points of the sound wave and it is logarithmic.

content.title: ¿Did you know?
content.text: Hertz unit was named after Heinrich Rudolph Hertz. He has nothing to do with the unit (or music) but proved the existence of electromagnetic waves and, to honour that, the unit was named after him.

texts: Depending on the amplitude, the human ear can detect frequencies from 20Hz up to 20kHz. A standard piano's lowest note is around 27.5Hz and the highest is around 4186Hz.

Some people still advocate that the standard should be 432Hz, also knows as Verdi's A, using arguments like: it's mathematically consisten with the univers; transmits beneficial healing energy, because it is a pure tone of math fundamental to nature; or acussing Joseph Goebbels (yes, the Nazi one) of forcing the adoption of 440Hz to provoke bad energy in the people.
